section.title: Intro to Linear Transformations
section.introduction: Another benefit of the matrix form A\vec{x} = \vec{b} of a linear system is that it allows us to view a matrix A as an object that acts on a vector \vec{x} to produce a new vector A\vec{x}.

subsection.title: Linear Transformations
subsection.definition:
A transformation (or mapping) T form \mathbb{R}^n to \mathbb{R}^m is a rule which assigns to each vector \vec{x} \in \mathbb{R}^n a vector T(\vec{x}) in \mathbb{R}^m.
The set \mathbb{R}^n is called the domain of T (more generally, a subset of \mathbb{R}^n, denoted by D(T)), and \mathbb{R}^m is called the codomain of T
For \vec{x} \in \mathbb{R}^n, the vector T(\vec{x}) is called the image of \vec{x}.
The range of T is the set of all images T(\vec{x}).
